Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of High-Flow Nasal Oxygen vs. Laryngeal Mask Ventilation in Hysteroscopic Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: This single-center, randomized, noninferiority trial was conducted in a university hospital in Rome, Italy, from September 2022 to June 2023.

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were ASA class I and II patients undergoing elective operative hysteroscopy.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomized 1:1 to receive either HFNO (70 L/min, 100% oxygen) or LMV (volume-controlled ventilation).

Objective.evidence: This trial assessed whether HFNO is noninferior to laryngeal mask ventilation (LMV) in terms of intraoperative respiratory support success during 30-minute general anesthesia.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was intraoperative respiratory support success, defined as SpO2 ≥ 94% and tcCO2 < 65 mm Hg without rescue interventions.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed in sealed envelopes.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 180 patients were randomized (90 per group) and analyzed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 180 patients were randomized (90 per group) and analyzed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Intraoperative respiratory support was successful in 99% of patients in both groups (absolute difference 0, unilateral 95% CI, 3%, noninferiority P < .001).

Harms.evidence: Postoperative respiratory symptoms were significantly lower in the HFNO group (2% vs. 19%, P < .001).

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by Fisher and Paykel Healthcare.
